title: Force and Laws of Motion
subject: Physics
learning_objectives: Learn Newton's three laws of motion
Apply laws to solve simple problems

sections.title: What is Force?
sections.content:
Force is a push or pull that can change the state of motion of an object. Force can:

• Start or stop motion
• Change the speed of motion
• Change the direction of motion
• Change the shape of an object

Force is measured in Newtons (N). It is a vector quantity with both magnitude and direction.

sections.title: Newton's First Law - Law of Inertia
sections.content:
**Statement:** An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction, unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

**Inertia** is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion.

**Examples:**
• Passengers lurch forward when a bus stops suddenly
• A ball keeps rolling until friction stops it
• Dust flies off when you beat a carpet

sections.title: Newton's Second Law
sections.content:
**Statement:** The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.

**Formula:** F = m × a

Where:
• F = Force (in Newtons)
• m = Mass (in kilograms)
• a = Acceleration (in m/s²)

**Example:** A 10 kg object accelerates at 5 m/s²
Force = 10 × 5 = 50 N

sections.title: Newton's Third Law
sections.content:
**Statement:** For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

**Examples:**
• When you push against a wall, the wall pushes back on you
• A rocket expels gas downward, and the gas pushes the rocket upward
• When you walk, you push the ground backward, and the ground pushes you forward

**Note:** Action and reaction forces act on different objects, so they don't cancel out.

sections.title: Momentum
sections.content:
**Momentum** is the quantity of motion of an object.

**Formula:** p = m × v

Where:
• p = Momentum (in kg·m/s)
• m = Mass (in kg)
• v = Velocity (in m/s)

**Law of Conservation of Momentum:** In a closed system, the total momentum before a collision equals the total momentum after the collision.

key_points: Force is a push or pull measured in Newtons
First Law: Objects resist changes in motion (inertia)
Third Law: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction

quiz_questions.question: What is the SI unit of force?
quiz_questions.explanation: The SI unit of force is Newton (N), named after Sir Isaac Newton.

quiz_questions.question: A 5 kg object is pushed with a force of 20 N. What is its acceleration?
quiz_questions.explanation: Using F = ma, we get a = F/m = 20/5 = 4 m/s²

quiz_questions.question: Which law explains why seatbelts are important in cars?
quiz_questions.explanation: The Law of Inertia (First Law) explains that your body continues moving forward when the car stops suddenly.

quiz_questions.question: When a gun fires a bullet, the gun recoils. This is an example of which law?
quiz_questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law: For every action (bullet going forward), there is an equal and opposite reaction (gun recoiling backward).
